CatDescriptText: Mr. Sidney King, maintenance, Third Ward and Mr. William (Bill) Kemmler, salesman, Canonsburg, was part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, April 15, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "In dispensing political patronage jobs to various groups, what should bet eh determining factor- the financial contribution of that group to the party, or the number of votes the group casts for the party?" Mr. Sidney King's answer reads: "I don't think it should be based on money contributions.  I think most jobs should be given out on the basis of ability.  I emphasize that I definitely do not believe the dispensers of the jobs should be concerned about contributions, but instead, the merit of the person."  Mr. William (Bill) Kemmler's answer reads: I don't think either... I think the basis should be merit, that is, whether or not the person can do the job...if he or she can't do the job, there's no good in having them there."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Sidney King wearing light colored fedora with dark stripe and moustache, standing in front of ribbed metal wall; Portrait of William "Bill" Kemmler wearing eyeglasses and coat, standing in front of C.A. Michel sign, Smithfield Street, Downtown, another version
